title: Painting of the lands marshes and swamps of the town of Bogotá
description: A legal map/painting created as evidence in a 1614 land ownership dispute between the crown prosecutor and Francisco Maldonado y Mendoza over lands in the Bogotá savannah. This unique document functions as both cartographic evidence and landscape painting, notable for being signed by its creator.
creator: Juan de Aguilar Rendón (painter) and Alonso Ruiz Gadálmez (guarantor)

title: Recopilación de Leyes - On the Creation of Audiencias
description: Legal document from the Recopilación de Leyes de los Reynos de las Indias (1681) detailing the establishment and jurisdictions of colonial audiencias, the highest royal courts in Spanish America.
creator: Antonio de León Pinelo (compiler)
credit: Recopilación de Leyes de los Reynos de las Indias, 1681

title: Portrait of Francisco Maldonado y Mendoza
description: 18th century portrait of Francisco Maldonado y Mendoza, encomendero and landowner who commissioned the 1614 painting to defend his land rights in the Bogotá savannah.
creator: Unknown artist, 18th century school

title: Recopilación de Leyes - On the Distribution of Encomiendas
description: Legal document from the Recopilación de Leyes de los Reynos de las Indias (1681) governing the distribution and administration of encomiendas, grants of Indigenous tribute and labor.
creator: Antonio de León Pinelo (compiler)
credit: Recopilación de Leyes de los Reynos de las Indias, 1681

title: Drawing of Santa Fe de Bogotá by Guamán Poma
description: Illustration of Santa Fe de Bogotá from Felipe Guamán Poma de Ayala's Nueva Corónica y Buen Gobierno (1615), offering an Indigenous perspective on the colonial city.
creator: Felipe Guamán Poma de Ayala
credit: From Nueva Corónica y Buen Gobierno, c. 1615

title: Framework of Kogi Loom
description: Drawing of a Kogi weaving loom framework, illustrating how Indigenous cartographic knowledge can be embedded in material culture. Among the Kogi people of Colombia's Sierra Nevada, looms represent both geographic space and the human body.
creator: Gerardo Reichel-Dolmatoff (illustrator)
credit: From ethnographic studies of Kogi material culture

title: Map of the West Indies
description: 16th century Venetian map showing early European cartographic representations of the Americas, demonstrating the diversity of mapmaking traditions across cultures and time periods.
creator: Venetian cartographer

title: Medieval World Map
description: Medieval mappa mundi representing the world according to European Christian cosmology, with Jerusalem at center. Demonstrates pre-modern cartographic conventions distinct from scientific mapmaking.
creator: Medieval cartographer

title: Babylonian World Map
description: Ancient Babylonian clay tablet depicting the known world as a circle surrounded by water, one of the oldest surviving maps. Shows radically different cartographic assumptions from modern conventions.
creator: Babylonian scribe

title: Codex Quetzalecatzin
description: Indigenous Mexican codex using pictographic conventions to represent territorial boundaries and genealogies, demonstrating Mesoamerican cartographic traditions that differ from European mapmaking.
creator: Indigenous Nahua artist

title: Siberian Sealskin Map
description: Map drawn on sealskin by Indigenous Siberians, representing geographic knowledge through materials and conventions specific to Arctic maritime cultures.
creator: Indigenous Siberian cartographer

title: Greenland Inuit Map
description: Inuit map of Greenland coastal geography, demonstrating Arctic peoples' sophisticated spatial knowledge encoded in formats distinct from Western cartographic traditions.
creator: Inuit cartographer

title: Portrait of Antonio Maldonado de Mendoza
description: 18th century portrait of Antonio Maldonado de Mendoza, descendant of Francisco and member of the powerful Maldonado lineage that held the Marquisate of San Jorge for two centuries.
creator: Unknown artist, 18th century school

title: Maldonado Family Tree
description: Genealogical document showing the Maldonado de Mendoza family lineage, illustrating two centuries of elite colonial power that produced viceroys, bishops, and eventually connected to republican-era leaders like Jorge Tadeo Lozano.
creator: Genealogist or family chronicler
